body.p:
My brother's departure enables me to send
you amot for the doz Bibles and 4 Prayer Books had from you
last year. As these Books sell very slowly, I have requested
him that you may not be kept out of the money any longer,
to pay you for them. You have never let me know what the
set of Books for my nephew cost; please do so and I will
remit the same p first opportunity. Osorio Wright & Co handed
me last Septr 49 Roads to Faith, for which I settled with my
brother, and he with you. there still remain unsold from that
shipment 6 Dias's letters 6 Bible texts, 7 select sentences, 24
Scriptural Questions & 12 Catechisms for younger children.
The Books p Responsible are still on hand, in very bad
condition, having been damaged by salt-water. So much
for business.

My brother will give you all the news about myself.
He will tell you of the discomforts and uncertain nature
of the situation I hold, and the growing incapability of this
congregation, owing to the adverse condition of trade, to
maintain a minister. My life is embittered by the petty
quarrels, which groundlessly, are fomented by the various

cliques into which this little community is split, and
of which I am made the scape-goat and victim. When
there is no minister, they mangle among themselves,
and when there is one, they unite and land themselves
against him. I challenge the wisest and best-tempered
man to live with them in harmony and concord.
The are unsociable and mean beyond description.
Were it not that my experience of them in years gone
by determined me to make a contract so stringent
and binding that they could not break through, they
would ere this have sent me to the right about. And
this angers them. Those who were opposed to having a
minister, and those who were favorable thereto, being now
united in sentiment against the unfortunate individual
holding that office. Individually and collectively
they urge nothing against me personally, for I do my
duty in and out of Synagogue punctiliously, but the
taxes for the payment of my salary fall heavily, and
they feel that I am a burthen, and a drain on their
pockets. I have offended one man, my chief supporter
and friend before and after my coming, because I refused
to accommodate myself to his ? and caprices, and
to the friend of his friends, and the enemy of his enemies.
he has loaded me with gross abuse and insult

got up cabals against me, without the least cause,
except that I am friendly with one of the leading men
of the congregation, when the mortally hated His family,
even his wife and children condemn his conduct, so
do his relatives and friends, but his commercial standing
enables him to have a tail of mischeivous people, who
to flatter him and obtain favors, circulate his דבות רעות.
The way public worship is carried on would, in any
other congregation, be considered excellent; and leave nothing
to be desired. Young and old members who have been lately
in Europe found it superior to what they witnessed there
and give it the preference. Only Marks's Synagogue was is
thought by some superior. If the prayers were somewhat
curtailed, and a better mode of chaunting introduced,
no fault could be found. You will think these are
easy of adoption. Not so mon cher, the slightest attempt
at change would sur le champ cause rows and
disturbances. A new element of mischief has recently
appeared. The notorious Mr. M B Simmonds, now
a disciple of Colento, declines his unbelief in the Jewish
scripture, avows himself a Unitarian, not in the
Christian meaning of the word, but what you and I
and others would call a Deist, and gave a proof
of his being one, by refusing lately in a court of justice,

to be sworn on the Hebrew Bible, alleging, when asked by
the Judge what he was, that he believed in God. The dark
depravity of the man was subsequently brought to light;
for the man party against whom he gave evidence proved from
Simmonds's own account books, written by himself, that
he was a perjurer and had given false testimony, as those
books negatived the whole of his deposition. He has
many followers; and now he refuses to pay his Synagogue
quota, assigning before the court that he is no longer
a Jew. What the Government will decide is yet unknown.
If the sentence be unfavorable to the Synagogue, then
many will follow suit and as they will consist of the
largest contributing members, you can conceive what my
position will be worth. Looking at it in the most favor-
able point of view, my tenure of office cannot, under
all these circumstances, be my lasting. Nevertheless
I shall hold on, pursue the even tenor of my way, and
calmly await the issue, in full reliance on His הרעה אתי מעודי עד היום הזה
Hebrew. As the congregation sought me and not
I them, and induced me to resign greater pecuniary benefit
than they offered me; it would be injustice on their part
to turn me adrift if they could, and as my contract
cannot be violated by them so summarily, I imagine it
will terminate in some compromise. I furnish you

with this general outline, leaving my brother to fill up
the picture, that you may form just conclusions on
the subject, and defend me from misrepresentation,
as becomes a friend, should I be attacked. I do not
wish to appear before the public in print under such mortifying
and unpleasant circumstances, and will not, unless it be a
dernier ressort to protect my name and character. It
is not improbable we may see one another again face
to face, for as I see no fixity here, and will have to look
for bread elsewhere, the states will be the most likely
place to pitch my tent. I seriously thought that St.
Thomas would be my resting place. I have been deceived,
tho' doubtlessly my removal therefrom will have been ordained
for the best. My constitution is stronger (JG) than ever
it was, and a cold climate may brace it, and fit me
for continuance of labor. The principal thing I seek
is peace; here I am not certain of it for a day, or rather
a day's peace is an unusual occurrence.

Where is Gutheim? I hope in his old place in N/O.
From the Occident I learn of H S. Jacobs's welfare.
J. P. Benjamin left here for Europe yesterday in the
B. S. Seine. I had a long conversation with him before

his departure. He told me in a general way of his
many hair-breadth escapes in disguises thro' Georgia
and Florida. He made his way ? in an open
boat, navigated by two men, to Cuba, whence he came
to St. Thomas. Gels Walker and Preston were with him.
From the date of his leaving Richmond till his arrival
at Havannah, over 4 months, his life he said was a
blank, in so far as his knowledge of events during that
time was concerned. Genl. Breckenridge sailed
from here two a month previously. From him we
learnt that Wm. Benjamin was then in Florida.
At When Jefferson Davis was captured, they were
only 40 miles in advance, and therefore had a narrow
escape. One old register Book of births gives the
date of Benjamin's age. He was born in St. Croix on the
6th August 1811 and circumcised by Judah Benjamin,
an uncle, I suppose.

My letter is full enough in all conscience, and
so you will no doubt think it. I perceive you
are proceeding in your usual useful career, and
read with much interest the transactions of your
American Board of Jewish Deputies, yourself in
the chair. What think you of 6 Israelites out of
a population of little more than 40,000 being returned

as members to the British Parliament whilst in
the states, with superior advantages, without a junction
of Church and State, our brethren are so much in
the back-ground. And then these men, one and
all, do not hold themselves aloof from commercial
interests, but take an active stand in them. Witness
the magnificent collection of £10,000 lately in aid
of the London Jews Free School, and the princely contribu
tions to synagogues, charities, and schools. Both the
Barons Rothschild, Alderman Salomons, Sir Francis
Goldsmid and his brother, and Baron Lionel's son
are all foremost in devotion to the welfare of their
people. They are not Jews in name, but live Kosher,
and are in their places at synagogue as well as in
the Counting House. I hear however ,that Baron Lionel
is paralytic, but hope it is not true. Professor
Sylvester who has solved what Newton left
improved, was once a pupil of mine; I taught him
Hebrew in Liverpool.

Good bye; Mrs. Nathan, Mrs. Samson, & David
join me in best wishes, and hoping that your
health is robust, and that you will make my
brother's residence in your city agreeable, I am
